results.title: Veterans of the road
results.creator_credit: Esso Petroleum and Veteran Car Club of Great Britain
results.brief_description: Tells the lighthearted story of a Veteran Car Club Rally of vintage cars, held at Abingdon, in Berkshire. Of quaint appearance (none of a later vintage than 1916) and still lively performance, they are seen being submitted to tests of speed, braking and steering, to the delight of many onlookers.

results.title: Veteran cars in Australia
results.creator_credit: Cine Service, H Sleigh and Geoffrey Thompson
results.brief_description: In 1956 Victoria staged its Annual Veteran Car Rally over a two day period and required cars to journey from Melbourne to Ballarat and back again. Among competing cars was a 1906 Argyle, 1908 Fiat, 1914 Napier and 1914 Standard. A Cadillac built in 1913 was declared the outright winner. The annual rally provided owners of old cars to show the public the steadiness, dependability and elegance of their automobiles. Narrated by Ray Chapman.

results.title: Vesalius, founder of modern anatomy
results.creator_credit: Yale University School of Medicine, Thomas R. Forbes and Susan Wheeler
results.brief_description: Documentary on Andreas Vesalius, born in 1514 in Brussels. Appointed Professor of Anatomy at Padua in 1536, he revolutionised anatomy with clear and succint lectures and dissections of cadavers. In 1543 his seven books on the structure of the human body was published - a comprehensive work which describes bones, muscles, blood vessels, nervous system, abdominal and thoracic viscera and head. The work corrected anatomical myths dating back to Roman times and emphasised the wholistic structure of the body. His use of detailed illustrations and emphasis on dissection and observation paved the way for modern anatomy and physiology.

results.title: Very nice very nice
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Colin Low, Tom Daly and Arthur Lipsett
results.brief_description: Arthur Lipsett’s first film. It looks behind the business-as-usual face we put on life and shows anxieties we want to forget. It is made of dozens of pictures that seem familiar, with fragments of speech heard in passing and, between times, a voice saying, “Very nice, very nice.”

results.title: Very important person [Study extract]
results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, Society for Education in Film and Television, Julian Wintle, Leslie Parkyn and Ken Annakin
results.brief_description: An extract from “Very Important Person”, directed by Ken Annakin. Features Farrow’s relations with other prisoners who suspect him of being a spy, his accidental discovery of the escape tunnel, and his encounter with the Camp Commandant on parade. Cast includes James Robertson Justice, Leslie Phillips, Stanley Baxter, Eric Sykes, Richard Wattis.

results.title: Very dangerous
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Crawley Films and James Hamilton
results.brief_description: This film deals with the extent, transmission, symptoms and treatment of gonorrhoea and syphilis. Animated diagrams illustrate the male anatomy and the course of infection. The value of blood tests and early proper treatment are emphasised. Through cooperation with health authorities and with knowledge these very dangerous venereal diseases can be wiped out. Revised version of the Royal Canadian Air Force Film, It’s Up to You (307799)

results.title: Very bad things
results.creator_credit: Initial Entertainment Group (US), Interscope Communication, Ballpark Productions, Cindy Cowan, Michael Schiffer, Diane Nabatoff and Peter Berg
results.brief_description: Very bad things is a very grim tale of morality and the bond between killers. Kyle Fisher is about to marry Laura, a neurotic, insecure woman, whose wedding plans are being administered by her in a caustic, shrill manner. Kyle’s four best friends - Adam, Michael, Charles and Robert - decide to take him to Vegas for the bucks turn, complete with drugs, booze and strippers. On the night in question one man accidentally kills a prostitute. Encouraged by Robert (Christian Slater) the group decide to bury the body in the desert. Before they can do this however a security guard discovers their crime and is promptly dispatched of also. With two bodies to dispose of the men are drawn into a gruesome pact that will assuredly be their undoing. Upon their return home the friends exchange increasingly bitter and acrimonious accusations as they attempt to deal with their misdeeds. Cameron Diaz plays Laura - the bride who will stop at nothing to have her wedding day perfect, disguising the moral degradation of those around her. Peter Berg makes his directorial debut with this very dark comedy that evokes the spirit of Tarantino, the Coen bothers and Danny Boyle. Also stars: Jeanne Tripplehorn, Daniel Stern and Jon Favreau.

results.title: Very Annie Mary
results.creator_credit: Film Four International, Arts Council of Wales, Studio Canal+, Arts Council of Great Britain, Damian Jones, Graham Broadbent and Sara Sugarman
results.brief_description: Annie Mary (Rachel Griffiths) is a simple-minded, clumsy, and kind-hearted twenty-something still living at home with her domineering, hypocritical, Pavarotti loving father in a small country town. Denied the chance to study singing in Milan at age sixteen due to the death of her mother, Annie has given up singing altogether and is barely hanging onto dregs of a dull romance with Colin, a man whom she has to bribe for sex. Just when it seems she may have a chance to have a life of her own, Annie Mary’s father has a stroke, and she is forced to take the reigns of his bakery and care for him at home. When Annie Mary realises that her best friend is dying, she desperately tries to raise money for a trip to Disneyland by forming a pop group and entering a talent contest, with one thousand pounds in prize money. A comedy of sorts, “Very Annie Mary” features several song and dance routines in the mode of “The Full Monty” and like that film, the depressed economy is the backdrop against which the townspeople hope to illicit a modicum of happiness from their penny pinching lives. Director Sara Sugarman is also responsible for the script.
